Title.evidence: Impact of Right Ventricular Dysfunction on Outcomes in CABG with or without SVR: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 1,000 patients with coronary artery disease, left ventricular ejection fraction ≤35%, and anterior dysfunction were randomised to undergo CABG or CABG + SVR.

Participants.evidence: 1,000 patients with coronary artery disease, left ventricular ejection fraction ≤35%, and anterior dysfunction were randomised to undergo CABG or CABG + SVR.

Intervention.evidence: randomised to undergo CABG or CABG + SVR.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether right ventricular (RV) dysfunction affects clinical outcomes in patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with or without surgical ventricular reconstruction (SVR).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint was all-cause mortality or cardiovascular hospitalization over a median follow-up of 48 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 1,000 patients with coronary artery disease, left ventricular ejection fraction ≤35%, and anterior dysfunction were randomised.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Baseline RV function was assessed in 866 patients using echocardiography.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Patients with moderate or severe RV dysfunction who received CABG + SVR had significantly worse outcomes compared to those who received CABG alone for both the primary endpoint (HR=1.86; CI=1.06–3.26; p=0.028) and the secondary endpoint of all-cause mortality (HR=3.37; CI=1.36–8.37; p=0.005).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
